awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Developing a Highly Selective, Orthogonal, Enzymatic RNA Labeling Technology via Directed Evolution of an RNA Transglycosylase
awd_abstract_narration:
Tools that facilitate the study of individual RNAs are critical for understanding their mechanisms of action and biological significance. RNAs are difficult to study as they vary in size, function, location, abundance, and lifetime. This project intends to engineer new enzymes that insert novel, small molecule reporters into an RNA in a manner that is appropriate for studying any RNA of interest. These enzymes will insert reporters that are small enough to not interfere with RNA function and do so in a manner that is specific to that individual RNA. These never-before-seen enzymes and small molecules will be programmed to work alongside their native counterparts without unwanted crosstalk, allowing researchers to efficiently investigate how location and abundance of RNAs influences their role in genetic mechanisms. The project will have broad impacts including improving societal literacy surrounding genetic mechanisms through presentation in accessible media platforms and increasing STEM exposure of underrepresented groups through local high school outreach. 

This research project intends to use directed evolution to discover new RNA modifying enzymes capable of exchanging a nucleobase in an RNA for a functional small molecule reporter. The directed evolution workflow will involve iterative rounds of site saturation mutagenesis and a unique high throughput screen to probe mutant transglycosylases for their ability to accept novel substrates. This technology avoids the limitations of state-of-the-art technologies, including bulky reporters, transient association, and off target installation. The enzyme will be evolved to act orthogonally to endogenous RNA modification enzymes and their substrates, facilitating high fidelity tagging and low background.  The versatility of this RNA modification strategy will provide investigators with an unprecedented tool to study their transcript of choice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
This project intended to engineer new enzymes that modify RNA in a manner that is appropriate for studying any RNA of interest. These enzymes are intended to attach fluorescent reporters specific to that individual RNA for which they are coded to interact with. During the lifetime of the award, we developed new methods to label tRNAs in mammalian cells for reporting on RNA post-transcriptional modification. We also developed methods to screen for modified enzymes that would be amenable to directed evolution through development of a yeast display approach. Finally, we engineered novel variants of RNA modifying enzymes that can modify RNA in living cells for imaging and tracking of long mRNAs. Importantly we demonstrated the ability to covalently modify RNAs for imaging applications, which represents an advance over approaches that use non covalent attachment of imaging probes. Overall, our findings set the foundation for future studies on establishing transglycosylases as tools for manipulating RNA both in vitro and in vivo. Our work could also enable new ways to control RNA function using covalent modification.

With respect to broader impacts of the work, this project provided opportunties for training of personnel and presentations of the research were given a local and national conferences.


Last Modified: 02/26/2025
Modified by: Neal K Devaraj
